text.p: Here are highlights of stories reported by Hungary's press, based on information by Nepszabadsag's Hungary Around the Clock service. For further details on how to subscribe to Hungary Around the Clock, please contact Monica Kovacs at (361) 351 7142 or fax your request to (361) 351 7141.
***GENERAL***
ALL PAPERS
- Hungarian gypsies held a candle-lit vigil outside Parliament on Saturday in memory of the gypsies killed in Auschwitz.
- Trade unions signed a declaration of intent on distributing mandates for the Health Insurance Authority governin body.
- The Romanian Foreign Ministry has severly criticized Cluj Mayor Gheorghe Funar saying his remakrs create trouble and tension and harm Romania's interests.
- Hungary is practically ready for NATO membership, President Arpad Goncz said in Prague.
- Austrian paper Der Standard said the handling of the so-called Operation Birch Tree demonstrates that politicians in power are untouchable when it comes to criminal matters.
MAGYAR NEMZET
- Gypsies have demanded collective compensation for their sufferings during World War II.
MAGYAR HIRLAP
- Opposition Christian Democrat party vice-president Zsolt Semjen said he will make a last effort to unite the party.
***BUSINESS***
ALL PAPERS
- Magyar Aluminium Rt and KAMM Metallwerke of Germany have agreed to establish an aluminium foundry in Varpalota.
NAPI GAZDASAG
- U.S.'s AES Summit, owner of the Tiszai power plant has bought a second coal mine in Hungary
- Telecommunications company MATAV Rt will have completed its national ISDN network by September.
- Polus Holding Rt will build a 7,000 square meters shopping mall in Barcs, on the Croatina border.
NEPSZABADSAG
- Hungary is the world's eighth most popular tourist destination.
